newsitem.title: USA: Three convicted for bomb hoax on Florida base.
newsitem.headline: Three convicted for bomb hoax on Florida base.

text.p: A court in Jacksonville has convicted a former sailor and two civilians of making bomb threats against the Naval Air Station here, a Navy spokeswoman said Wednesday.

Marshall Mayo, aged 21, Sherrie Lynn Tatum, 20, and Justin Thompson, 20, a former sailor in the U.S. Navy, were convicted Tuesday after a five-day trial of conspiracy to make bomb threats and making threats between April and July, spokeswoman Miriam Larue said.
Numerous threats were telephoned into the Naval Air Station's Hangar 1000, which handles routine maintenance and houses a naval flight training squadron and four anti-submarine warfare squadrons.
Witnesses testified that the threats were called in so the hangar would be evacuated and the defendants sent home from work.
The hangar operates a 24-hour, three-shift per day operation employing more than 3,000 military and civilian personnel.
Mayo and Thompson face up to 15 years in prison and a $750,000 fine and Tatum could receive up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine.
